_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Central Minnesota Renewables (CMR) is an ethanol fuel production plant located near Little Falls, in Morrison County, Minnesota.  As a requirement of the Clean Air Act Amendments 112(r) Accidental Release of Hazardous Air Substances program, Central Minnesota Renewables completed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for any chemical stored on-site above the RMP reporting threshold.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

CMR is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process, specifically pentane as a constituent of the natural gasoline used as the ethanol denaturant, as well as the aqueous ammonia.  The denaturant is added to the ethanol to make it unfit for human consumption.  The aqueous ammonia is used for pH control directly in the process feed mixture to fermentation.  It is the policy of CMR to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  In the event of an emergency, including accidental release of denaturant or aqueous ammonia, it is the policy of CMR to notify the Little Falls Fire Department and evacuate all employees at the facility.



Regulated Substances Handled

The facility produces fuel grade ethanol from corn; secondary byproducts include dry distillers grains with solubles and corn oil.  The fuel ethanol production process requires use of a denaturant (natural gasoline) which may contain up to 30 percent pentane, an RMP regulated substance.  The maximum amount of natural gasoline on-site is estimated to be 94,000 pounds (total pentane is 28,000 pounds).  The natural gasoline is stored in an above ground tank as a liquid and is introduced to the fuel ethanol in the final stage of production.  The denaturant tank is located in secondary containment with adequate capacity for the entire tank plus freeboard.  Aqueous ammonia is also stored on-site and used in the ethanol production process for pH control.  The

aqueous ammonia used at CMR contains up to 61 percent ammonium hydroxide.  The maximum ammonia stored will be 68,000 pounds.  CMR has evaluated worst and alternative case scenarios as it relates to each of these reportable substances.  Emergency response programs for these scenarios have been prepared and implemented.  CMR has coordinated emergency response with the local authorities and conducts drills.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Through completion of this RMP, CMR has complied with the EPA requirements under 40 CFR Part 68 and OSHA Process Safety Management requirements.  Process safety information and operations/maintenance procedures are documented on-site.  Periodic functions such as process hazard analysis, training, change management and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis.  Audits of the overall RMP will be conducted on a regular basis to assure compliance with EPA regulations.



Five Year Accident History

CMR does not have a history of accidents which may have caused death, injuries, environmental or property damage, evacuations or in-place sheltering in the last five years.  This facility began operations the week of February 26, 1999.



The Emergency Response Program

CMR has developed a written Emergency Response Plan, which includes, in part, response measures for chemical releases, an employee training program, and a schedule for periodic drills.  CMR is also incorporated into the community Emergency Response Plan and coordinates with the Little Falls Fire Department.
